Parents and families,

We wanted to let you know about an important resource to help families who are struggling because of the
pandemic. If your child was eating free or reduced-price lunch school lunch in March 2020, you are eligible for
food purchasing assistance of $250 per eligible child!
The Oklahoma Department of Human Services will be sending Pandemic Electronic Benefits Transfer benefits, or
P-EBT, to eligible families – you do not need to apply. If you already have an EBT card the benefits will be loaded
on your existing card. If you do not currently have an EBT card, please look out for a P-EBT card in the mail.
Watch closely as the outside envelope may not clearly say P-EBT.
P-EBT is provided to any child who was receiving free or reduced-price school lunch in March 2020. It will not
impact your citizenship or immigration status.

To learn more, visit www.hungerfreeok.org/pebt. Thank you!

Monday, August 31 is the first day for all of our students in traditional school to attend. It is very important that you screen your children before sending them to school. DO NOT SEND YOUR KIDS TO SCHOOL IF THEY EXHIBIT ANY SYMPTOMS OF COVID-19. Additionally, if you or anyone in your home has COVID-19, are exhibiting symptoms, or are awaiting test results, please do not send your kids to school.

WE STRONGLY RECOMMEND THAT ALL STUDENTS AND STAFF MEMBERS WEAR FACIAL COVERINGS WHILE ATTENDING SCHOOL.

This week, McCurtain County jumped two levels into Orange 2 again. This indicates we have high levels of transmission of Covid-19 in our community. There are a number of active cases in the Valliant community. We currently have several members of our staff and a number of students in quarantine. We are trying to do what we can. We need your help to curb the spread and prevent others from contracting the virus.

We want to be in school. Our ability to remain in school depends on everyone doing their part.

Mask up! It’s a Great Day to be a Bulldog!

We want to help. We love our kids.

post_text: Ms. Vaught’s STEM classes recently visited the Oklahoma Geological Survey OPIC in Norman. Students received “hands on” learning experiences in the field of geology. In addition, they met an anthropologist, seismologist, petroleum geologist and a field geologist and could ask questions. The students learning experience was not over at the end of the trip. They returned with fossils and minerals to research as well as their very own Raspberry Shake Seismometer. The Raspberry Shake will be producing real-time data which is sent to and used by OGS seismic analysts. If the device detects an earthquake, scientists will use that data right away to start figuring out where the earthquake happened and how big it was! That makes our students true citizen scientists! This is the first seismometer placed in our area by a research group.
